comments.commentBody:
A bit of confusion in the article as to how the Times interprets Hispanics as a group. Being Hispanic is an ethnicity, a cultural marker, not a race.

"The data on Hispanic turnout is not as illustrative elsewhere in the country, because most other states do not ask about race and Hispanic origin on voter registration forms. But this is a national trend." This appears to reflect voters being asked about their Hispanic origin first, and their race secondly, a clear indication that the two are separate. However, elsewhere in the article, the Times indicates that polling data "was based on the race that registered voters self-reported to pollsters, not the race that they indicated on their voter registration form."

If there is confusion about race vs ethnicity within the NYT, it would be great to see that confusion cleared up in the near future, as per its rightfully superior standards of journalism.

A Mexican-American friend of mine here in red, red Idaho, obtained her U.S. citizenship a few months ago.  She traveled over to Boise for the ceremony, had a friend take a picture of her right after the ceremony, with her holding a small American flag.   She was so proud and texted me and sent the photo!   When I talked to her a few days later I asked her if she had registered to vote.  "The first thing I did", she replied.   When early voting started here in Idaho Falls she again texted me to proudly tell me she voted!! - for Hillary!!
This surge may be true. Most of my white Hispanic friends are college-educated and will be voting for Clinton.
Bravo to my daughter who went from Los Angeles to East Las Vegas to work on the Clinton campaign to get out the vote in Hispanic areas.

Wouldn't it be amazing and wonderful if our last two Presidents ( assuming a Hillary win), an African American, and a woman, were elected because of our African American population and our Latino population! Wouldn't this tell Donald Trump and his ardent supporters, wishing to return to the white supremacy days of our past, that our nation is now diverse and proud of it! And, that is why America is great!

This election is not about any particular slice of America showing up. It is about Hispanics, college-educated whites (men and women), Asians, Blacks and yes, even the 40% of non-college educated Whites picking decency and experience over a malignant tumor. We are all gathering together in all our diversity to choose the message of unity (and whatever remnants of hope we have left from hope and change) for our kids and our fellow Americans. But it is a great thing that more Hispanics are showing up to join this unity than ever before.
Previously, the only reliable Latino vote was Cuban, and they went republican. Today, Central and S. Americans are voting and they appear more democratic. Either way it's great for democracy.
Hispanics will hopefully save us white americans from Trump.
Gracias Donald, for your, "Loco Boca." You did more with your hate than all the love in the world could hope for.
So if you tell people they're a bunch of rapists and murderers and their judges can't possibly be objective, they get angry? Who knew? How sweet it is.

The really dumb thing is the Republicans - and Trump - knew that the lack of Latino support cost them the campaign in 2008 yet their candidate still went out there with all this craziness about a border wall and many other slurs. Did they think the millions of people who would take offence at these remarks would just shrug them off and forget all about it coming election day? Stupid.

The smaller margin Clinton has under Trump in traditionally red states like TX, NM and AZ is what will win her the small margin for the presidency. And that will be thank u to the sleeping giant of the Latino vote.

I am a white, college-educated female from the Midwest, and I am thrilled to see the growing political voices of our Hispanic, African-American, and LGBTQ sisters and brothers in this country. We just need to make sure that some of other under-represented demographic groups have their political voices heard as well. I truly believe that the greatest thing about the United States of America is the diversity of its people.  It is our strength, our uniqueness of character, and will help to KEEP America great.

Poetic justice if the Hispanic vote turns out to be decisive in Hillary's victory. Trump's racist anti-immigration latino discourse will be defeated at the polls.

Despite shortcomings, democracy is still the best political system to handle deplorable candidates like Donald Trump.

Come on Florida!! Vote Vote Vote! I want to relax by 8:30 PM, secure in the knowledge that Trump has been dealt a knock out blow and that the world is still round.
We still love you America. Faults and all, you are the greatest evolving human experiment, and it is awesome to witness.
The comment section here has brightened my day in bleary and blustery Britain

There's a famous saying by John F Kennedy "Victory has a hundred fathers and defeat is an orphan" and when it comes to victory you have multitudes of father-factors and triggers which add fillip to its culmination and accomplishment. During these polls, the polarization of voters in their cocoon and ethnic hamlets have brought out one stark glaring fact that though America is a global cosmopolitan society, when it comes to preference of choice and casting ballots, the marginal segmentation of the societal fabric splits into the hinges and seams of Hispanics,, Latinos, Afro-Americans, chino-schetzwan and Asian cultures with its own impact and influences. The poll of polls clearly depicts that Trump brigade is losing his ground while mustering votes from Hispanics, Latinos and Afro-Americans and immigrants . His bolstering strength, forte and area of dominance being white Caucasian race and conservative whites who still hold the roots of true Yankee-doodle Americanism. If large turn about and surge of Hispanic voters is seen in the states of Nevada and Florida, it will seal the fate of Clinton, with a comfortable score of victory. Likewise Trump is  largely depending on those fringe voters, that undecided lot and fence-shifters who would and could swing from red to blues. The game is still dicey and yo-yoing between the two goal-posts.As the clock ticks for the final gong, its last leg of the race, Dems are gradually sniffing and smelling some victory lavender for thumbs up !!

'Vaya con los Angeles' a house mover told me when I was young. Funny what one remembers late in life, singular that I always have taken it for granted that Hispanics and Latinos are just as American as I am. In 2012, applications for Green Cards were being turned down, and there was a scam lottery that was circulating asking for $600 to collect one's citizenship.

Thinking of my friend of many years who was born in Puerto Rico and has helped me all these years, while we have navigated the Recession together. Proud of her two grown children who made it on scholarship to college. Remembering when we smiled over a picture of Trump in diapers, squalling and bright pink-looking in a bath salts sort of way, full of an alert but dithering energy.

Her boyfriend, a gentle giant of a man with grown children of his own, he is American and not from the Dominican Republic. Whether they vote is none of my business, but they are not going to support Trump in this dark hour of American history. Stand with the Angels and be well, we will prevail and do the Right Thing.

Trump said nasty hateful things about Latino people such as Miss Universe and all Mexicans. For the media to report what he himself said is not bias. This myth that the media is biased is ridiculous. Its like saying journalists that opposed Pol Pot in Cambodia were biased. Shining a light on miscreants is not bias.
He generates a poor image not because the media reports it but because he brags himself about entering dressing rooms of women unasked and groping women unasked. How is it biased to a) report it and b) criticise it in opinion pieces?
Thank goodness for Latinos. You have saved the USA.

We support Donald Trump because we want the Philippines and the USA to have respect for each other. We need the trump train in the Philippines to connect people and create jobs. The idea of "free immigration" is silly because Mexicans need jobs in Mexico and a wall will stop guns and drugs. Vite for Trump if you love your country, wherever you're from.
While Trump's been busy fantasizing about his wall on the Rio Grande, Latinos have been quietly and quickly building a real wall on the Potomac. And it's a most bigly beautiful wall.

At its best, what America stands for is that it does not matter what your race, culture or former nationality is once you come here permanently.  If you become American, and you strive to make America better in your own individual way, this is what matters today.  So a shout out to all who have done their part today.  And an exhortation to those who have failed us in their duty, especially Congress, to remember your duty.
If so, it would be a fitting reply to Trump and his Hispanic bashing.

replies.commentBody:
@Conservative Democrat
WV

Are you confused by Italian flags at Columbus day parades? How about Irish flags at St Paddy's day parades?

comments.commentBody:
I welcome the assimilation of Hispanic immigrants into the voting American mainstream culture,

Did it confuse me to see rallies in the US where the Mexican, and not the US flag, was being waved? Absolutely.

But I hope the adoption of American culture, the English language and the love of this country and its freedoms will be what we see moving forward by all Latino and other first generation immigrants. It will make our melting pot process much less divisive.

I am thrilled to read there is a strong surge of Hispanics voting. I hope it lasts, and becomes a habit, even when the Republican candidate is not a divisive hate monger. I hope all those who are disenfranchised realize the power of the vote.

White folks, specifically Republicans, have. They will be there consistently, especially in off-year elections. In 2018 they will be there to obstruct Hillary like they did Barack. This is an important thing to take away from this election. Imagine all the Republicans who are actually more dangerous than Trump, they are real politicians who have passed laws. Trump may hog all the bluster, but it is Mike Pence who has done actual damage. Take a look at what he did as governor of Indiana. Take a look at what Cruz has done in Texas, and Rubio in Florida.

These guys may appear like milquetoasts compared with The Donald, but they are the sly sneaky ones who effect legislation. One should fear them more than Trump. They are the wolves in sheep's clothing. Remember that in two years.

DD
Manhattan
